content: The "National September 11 Memorial & Museum Commemorative Medal Act of 2010" authorizes the striking of 2,000,000 silver medals commemorating the 10th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks. The design of the medals must symbolize the courage, sacrifice, and strength of the victims and heroes of that day. The "National September 11 Memorial & Museum Commemorative Medal Act of 2010" authorizes the striking of 2,000,000 silver medals commemorating the 10th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks. The medals will bear inscriptions of the years "2001-2011" and the words "Always Remember." The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The medals will be of high quality and struck at only 2 designated US Mint facilities. The "National September 11 Memorial & Museum Commemorative Medal Act of 2010" authorizes the striking of 2,000,000 silver medals commemorating the 10th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks. The medals will be considered numismatic items and will be struck at the United States Mint facilities in West Point, New York, and Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The Secretary may make the medals available for sale starting January 1, 2011, and no medals shall be struck after December 31, 2012. The medals struck under the "National September 11 Memorial & Museum Commemorative Medal Act of 2010" are national medals for sale by the Secretary at a price including design costs, surcharges, and bulk sales discounts. Introductory orders will also be accepted at a reasonable discount. Sales of medals under this Act will include a $10 surcharge per medal, with all surcharge proceeds going to support the National September 11 Memorial & Museum at the World Trade Center. The Comptroller General of the United States will audit the museum's expenditures related to these funds. SEC. 8. BUDGET COMPLIANCE. The budgetary effects of this Act shall be determined by reference to the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010.
